Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Damage Compliant Inelastic Design Parameters for Performance-Based-Seismic-Design of Slender RC Columns

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop and calibrate inelastic modeling parameters that better correlate damage to performance of slender reinforced concrete (RC) bridge columns. The specific modeling parameter to be investigated is the so-called plastic hinge length, which facilitates design and analysis tasks related to inelastic behavior. The approach will employ a mechanics-based methodology and progress from simple computational tools to high-fidelity modeling of the inelastic response of RC columns. Linking of these computational tools to a rigorous experimental program with accurate localized measurements will provide the necessary data to validate and calibrate the new mechanics-based models. The research will result in newly calibrated/validated plastic hinge length models with improved correlation and/or compliance with local damage that develop in RC bridge columns during seismic loads. Deliverables include new models for defining plastic hinge length that balance the design convenience and the analytical rigor of mechanics, while providing accuracy in their ability to relate to damage.


Current state of the art in seismic design is moving towards prescribing localized strain levels that correlate to a well-defined damage level. If successful, the research will provide valuable numerical tools for practitioners and researchers to use in the assessment/design of RC columns within this emerging design philosophy. The research will create a unifying framework for inelastic modeling in performance based design, which will be applicable to a range of column sizes in bridge and building structures. Research results will be archived in open-access repositories for utilization by others. Educational resources for undergraduate and graduate students such as a virtual structural testing laboratory will be created to facilitate their learning. Outreach activities are planned for K-12 students and freshmen engineering students. The PIs will leverage the project with REU supplementary funding for summer research fellowships exclusively targeted at underrepresented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research, a new mass rig system for shaking table tests was developed that attempts to mitigate deficiencies present in current testing setups. This research investigated the influence of gravity loads and large displacement theory, generally known as second order P-delta effects, on the stability of RC bridge columns. One of the main outcomes is a displacement ductility performance limit state that considers the limit state at which slender RC bridge columns become unstable. Based on this displacement ductility performance limit state, design charts were developed. These charts can be used to obtain a displacement ductility that corresponds to the limit state when RC bridge columns become unstable under the combined actions of gravity and seismic loads. This is a significant improvement in the design of RC columns to resist P-Delta effects because other methods presented in the literature do not address the limit state when RC bridge columns become unstable under the combined actions of gravity and seismic loads.

Two PhDs and one Master’s student are currently working on this project. The Master’s student is a minority student and was previously supported by a supplementary NSF REU grant. Two articles acknowledging NSF support were published and presented during the 15th World Conference in Earthquake Engineering. Dr. Silva has also made presentations/poster to the (1) 2012 and 2013 committee meetings of the TRB Committee AFF50: Seismic Design of Bridges, (2) July CMMI 2012 Boston, and (3) 2012 and 2013 committee meetings of the ACI Committee ACI 341: Earthquake-Resistant Concrete Bridges. Recently, Dr. Silva submitted two more articles to the Journal of Earthquake Engineering and Structural Dynamics, and the ASCE Journal of Structural Engineering. The article submitted to the Journal of Earthquake Engineering and Structural Dynamics was approved iand it is ready for publication.

Part of this research prioject, the PI combined numerical and physical modeling to introduce concepts of structural stability to Freshman Engineering students. The prototype structure for this class was The Alamillo Bridge in Seville, Spain. This bridge was selected for this class exercise because the asymmetric inclined mast and the horizontal deck create a structural system that depends on these two components to maintain structural stability. The structural configuration of the Alamillo Bridge allow students to experience firsthand the concept of static equilibrium, whereby the cable stays transfer the forces necessary to create a mutual dependent system amongst the mast and deck.
